comments.commentBody: You can always tell a Republican columnist - but not much.
Great ideas are not in short supply.  If they are all you have to offer, you shouldn't even vote.
Persuader? Demagogue? Organizer?  Why not just elect someone with great ideas for a change?

Friends who live overseas tell me that the whole world is watching America with the sick fascination of one driving past a bad highway accident.

Partly it's the quality of debate, the narrowness of it: no discussion on topics relevant to the interests backing the candidates: nothing on 'fracking,' which is of great interest to Americans in NYC - all 8 million or so who are a little worried about the proposed site straddling our biggest source of fresh water. Though we're still dealing with lead abatement issues from the 19th & 20th Centuries, when landlords' wealth was of higher priority than their tenants' health... forgive us if we think further down the road than this quarter's profits.

The sad scene thus far is an all-too-reality show in which people representing 20th-C.- 1% values are reduced to squabbling about whether cheating on two (at minimum) wives is worse than making money by putting others out of work, or refusing to allow others the right to a choice you, yourself have made... or whether elements of the Constitution (several amendments of it, actually) should be repealed immediately so one does not have to use the toilet of a gay supporter... and audiences cheer for their worst impulses - rather than "the better angels of our nature," as Lincoln put it... and corporate media trumpets the "meaning" of these "elections" -- by a tiny fragment of the electorate in the state.

Meanwhile WI got 1,000,000 signatures to recall Walker/Kleefisch. Now THAT'S democracy.

It is no secret that entertainment sells, and our society is not grown up enough to be wooed by universities using a message of the value of an investment in research and education in place of the basic instincts attack of sports entertainment. Hence sports is here to stay.

Rather than complain about the professional nature of college sports, it would be far better to learn from their success. Wouldn't it be great if all programs at a university took a similar professional approach, emphasizing practical solutions of the worlds problems and commercial development of university research?

Let's let college athletes be real professionals and let's also encourage professors and students in engineering, the sciences and humanities to build companies and real world solutions out of their learning. That would be an investment of public resources we could be proud of, at least as proud as winning in sports.
Point taken, but it was "Horsefeathers," not "Duck Soup".

“In China and other parts of the world, there are no gigantic stadiums in the middle of campus. There is a laser focus on education as being the major thing. In the United States, we play football.”

Enjoy those football games kid, because your post college life is quite possibly going to be one of misery and deprivation.

I wish we could stop wasting time with "the system is rigged" lamentations. In a free society, more money creates more opportunity. That's just the way it is. The alternative is a never ending array of government controls and restrictions imposed in the pursuit of elusive "equality."

Why does a student have to be "considered for employment at the top companies" right out of college? When did that become the measurement of "fairness." Do what generations of students have done: go to a more affordable school, study and intern in your field, get a job where ever you can and work your way up.

"But the wealthy don't have to go that route!" True. Get over it. You have take the long road. If you succeed, your children or grandchildren may be the beneficiary of your "wealth."

There is somewhat of a "Catch 22", especially for the Middle Class in applying to the schools that will get you considered for employment at the top companies. If you come from a poor family--and just happen to have the academic capabilities--you just might get a scholarship.

Forty to fifty thousand per year, just for tuition, truly doesn't grow on trees. But, if you come from the Middle Class, had the advantage of pre-school programs and had books around the house and parents who fead to you, oftentimes you don't have a shot at Financial Aid. So, you're in the middle of the 99%.

Meanwhile, wealthy families don't sweat the high tuitions and, in many instances, have sway with some of there top universities through TAX-DEDUCTIBLE family endowments, being an alumnus, serving on boards together, or just knowing the right people (at the school). Just put your father or grandfather's business card in with your application.

In effect, the academic potential of the apple ant from the wealthy family might not matter. Stories abound about kids from the one percent families easy entry and sailing through four years without hardly cracking a book. IS THE SCHOOL GOPING TO FLUNK A STUDENT FROM A FAMILY THAT IS A EGULAR CONTRIBUTOR?

And what a return. Gallo came up big, as did Moz, and even Al Harrington (or No Sharrington, as we used to refer to him over at RealGM).

Kudos to Al Trautwig for opening tonight's broadcast with that quote from an unnamed scout: "The Knicks traded four starters for a celebrity." Never have truer words been spoken.

Mr. Dolan, did you hear them? What does Isiah say?

Obama did a great impression of Al Greenat.. Would have been superb if they had gotten Bill Clinton (in the shades) on the Sax.

No offense, but don't leave you day job, Mr. Prez. I want you to be there for another 4 years.

[After that, you, Bill and I can tour the world.]

All Obama needs is to show that he has some workable idea of how to fix things. People have gotten the idea that he is just floundering around and hoping for change and really has no idea of what is going on or what to do about it. They do not beleive that soaking the rich 1% for a few more tax dollars is going to help them much. It may be a good idea just for reasons of equity, but it does not sound like it is much of a way to fix the economy and create jobs. They like Obama as a person, but without a new plan or some real definitive signs of progress they will be forced to try someone else.  People want him to succeed, but they are in a world of hurt and they expect results and leadership and hope.

I don't think Obama feels sorry for himself or believes he is greater than the American people.  While there is a negative air in the economy and an unresponsive Republican Congress, Obama is painted with every flaw you can imagine - aloof, arrogant, naive, radical socialist, etc.  As the economy improves, the situation will change. Get 200k in net new jobs every month through July and his opponents will have nothing to run on.  Given the health care, stimulus, financial reform, and bin Laden wins, Obama will go down as one of the greatest Presidents in the modern era.

The NY Giants will prevail over the forty niners.  I am not an expert on football. However, I have observed a marked improvement in the Giants' defense.  Also, I think that Eli Manning will have a good day.  They also have a great coach.

Where in the Constitution does if give the minority the right to block a nomination. The Constitution says the Vice President an vote to break ties, otherwise the majority vote rules.

These Senate rules need to be changed to comply with the constitution. if a senator is going to filibuster, then he should be made to do that. Senator Inhofe is a tool of the petroleum industry, he is one of the most obstructionists senators.

It is despicable that people like Inhofe can prevent well qualified people from being appointed to protect the rest of us. He is an example of how money runs the Senate.An example of the most dishonest legislators in congress.

You said, "The outrage reminds me of the controversy over global warming. Yes, there are climate-change deniers. But nobody seems to notice that they’re in two totally different camps, making totally different arguments. Some people deny that there’s been any climate change at all. Others acknowledge the climate change, but deny that people have anything to do with it. These two categories of people actually aren’t on the same side at all."

I've been reading your writing for a long time and I still can't believe you went with this when it couldn't be more wrong. They are on the exact same side. They are both against doing anything to fix it. They have different reasons for that stance but the stance is the same nonetheless.

Camp A thinks this because they don't think there is a problem.
Camp B thinks this because if you believe we didn't cause it then changing our behavior won't fix it.

The most amazing part of this article is that you throw up multiple straw men and shoot them down while missing the actual point entirely. Our laws should not be set up using a shoot first, ask questions later mentality.

This is just one more in a long string of examples where the law would do far more harm (if not the only harm) to those that are actually not breaking the rules while those that are would easily circumvent the roadblocks put in place by it.
Best outfield player, given Brad Friedel's accomplishments. Nevertheless, Dempsey has been awesome this season.

Oops, actually, looking back at the 2008 election, Florida was more closely contested than Ohio, so that would make Florida the key state for Romney vs. Gingrich, the state exactly in-between red and blue that should theoretically determine the winner, assuming the demographics haven't changed that fact since 2008. That makes Tuesday even more interesting.

Romney is the more liberal candidate, so it stands to reason that he will need the blue states to win. Assuming he wins Utah because of Mormons, he will also need all of Obama's 2008 states except the two most contested and, hence, theoretically, the most conservative states, North Carolina and Indiana. According to this theory, Romney definitely needs Florida, so if he does lose Florida, I'd give Gingrich a greater than 50% chance of winning the nomination. Also according to this theory, Ohio will be the key state that determines the winner if it is close enough to come down to a single state.

Fact Boy, The "sleeper agent' you touched on, any notion as to how he got the nod?

WHH

Welcome back, Waggy-poo, your presence has always made WP all the more convivial.

Howie
Talk about advantages - I'm not sure it's possible to do this puzzle if you get stuck on42A because you don't live in Chicago. (I sure hope CHI stands for Chicago)
Suejean, I haven't filled in 42A yet because I'm holding out for NYC.
I don't know what Adam is doing but I went to see Snow White with my Mommy many years ago and he is ruining that experience for me.

Reverb, I, for one, am extremely enameled by your comment...tooth be known!

WHH

granbaer, Flattery, my good man, will get you everywhere in WP, however, we only recognize "true" genius when said enlightened individual announces to all those at the Round Table...that he's picking up the tab!

WHH

Fact Boy -- This is what that internet source of truth, Wikipedia, says:

Four presidents were members of the United States Whig Party:
1.William Henry Harrison (1841)
2.John Tyler (1841–1845)
3.Zachary Taylor (1849–1850)
4.Millard Fillmore (1850–1853)

Whig presidents have governed for 8 years in total.

Hello, can anyone tell me where I can find more of these 3D Word Hunt Puzzles? There only seems to be 3 different puzzles like this on the entire internet ( after doing extensive searches on Google). Thank you

If you had read the article carefully you would see that Obama is not the cause of the problem.  You could cut taxes to zero and it would not stop companies from outsourcing to places like China where employers can treat workers and the environment as shabbily as they please.  The only thing that will change this is US consumers refusing to go along with it, buying the cheapest product no matter what the consequences are.  The problem is you and me - not Obama.  At least Obama is smart enough to ask the right questions - and to try to do something about it.

People may have a problem with Apple for moving production overseas, but I have a problem with Obama for not even knowing why Apple has done so.

Obama is even more ignorant of business than I thought.

Oh, I think the extremists are the majority--25 % of SC voters in the military, 66% Evangelical Christians, 66% supporting the Tea Party. I'm not even remotely surprised that the state still waves a Confederate flag, that's the era they live in. And that's the era they want everyone else to live in.

I wouldn't enter South Carolina with a light tan.

.."and why don't they show up in force to pull down the Confederate flag that makes a mockery of their state capitol?"
A wonderful question. Of course, this despicable symbol of oppression also makes a mockery of the Declaration of Independence, the US Constitution, and two hundred years of American history.
Amen to that Stu! The Ron Paul movement still doesn't have any pull? What's up with that slackers???

South Carolinians who claim that the right-wing extremists who showed up to vote for Gingrich (and Santorum) do not represent the great majority of those who reside in their state need to ask themselves: where was everyone else on Primary day?  And, more importantly, where will they be come November?  And, for that matter, why don't they show up in force to pull down the Confederate flag that makes a mockery of their state capitol?  If you don't want to be associated with (or represented by) a despicable minority you first need to prove that you're part of the majority.

Problems with this:

1) Santorum would doubtless not be interested in State. He's a social conservative -- he doesn't know or care about diplomacy. He'd probably demand Justice, so he can throw abortionists in jail.

2) Rubio would probably lock down Florida for Newt but very little else. He's a Cuban-American and it is Central American Hispanics that make up most Hispanic voters. And the prospect of a slate from two southeastern states is not one that will go over well in the Midwest, which must be in play for Newt to win (the Northeast and Far West, of course, are hopeless for him anyhow.)

3) All of that said, the basis thesis that Newt will offer Santorum a lot to go away is sound. Romney, however, will also be offering him a lot to stay in.

4) Paul may very well go away -- to run as a Libertarian in November. He has a message he wants to get across and although I think it's a nutsy message, I respect him for the effort. However, it isn't working. Not only is he not winning over any of the Republican constituencies he needs to stay competitive, but he's beginning to be ignored even more than he was before, as Mitt-Newt-Rick take the lead. If he wants to remain relevant, he has to run as an independent or a Lib. Even if his presence helps in forcing a brokered convention, he's NOT going to be part of the brokering.

And he must make his decision soon, because if he waits too long he begins to encounter ballot issues in many states.
It could be worse.  They might not even have jobs.
